questions.question_text: A packet is destined for 10.10.1.22. Which static route does the router choose to forward the packet?

choices.B: It load-balances traffic between all three routes.
choices.D: It selects the RIP route because it has the longest prefix inclusive of the destination address.
choices.C: It chooses the OSPF route because it has the longest prefix inclusive of the destination address.
choices.A: It chooses the EIGRP route because it has the lowest administrative distance.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. How does the router manage traffic to 192.168.12.16?

discussion.content:
The answer is wrong. The router can't use the network OSPF because it's another network and not include the destination address (192.168.12.0/28 --> from 192.168.12.0 to 192.168.12.15). The correct answer is D because the RIP route use a /27 subnet and include the destination address (192.168.12.0/27 --> from 192.168.12.0 to 192.168.12.31).
If i wrong please correct me

comments.content: yes, D is correct because the C addresses are 192.168.12.0-> subnet address and the last 192.168.12.15-> broadcast address
You're right C is wrong D is correct

This completely depends upon if the 192.168.12.16 in the question is a destination network or host address. If it's the destination network then 192.168.12.0/28 is correct since 192.168.12.16 is a network and not a host IP. If 192.168.12.16 is a host IP then the answer is 192.168.12.0/27. In my opinion the question isn't clear but I read it as the destination network.
D is correct. C is wrong since 192.168.12.16 is outside the host address range; therefore, a mask of 255.255.255.224 is able to route traffic properly with RIP /27

And even if they wanted to make this a 'trickier' question, they should have had the last one as 192.168.12.16/28. It would include the address in the range but answer would still be D since .16 would be network address. Basically, a .16 address on a /28 network can never be a host address.
Even if it is not a host address, I am pretty sure the router will still chose the OSPF route in the case you described.

discussion.content: D is correct. OSPF with /28 does NOT include .16, stops at .14, .15 broadcast.

In routing, the prefix length (subnet mask or prefix length in CIDR notation) takes precedence over administrative distance (AD) when determining the best route to a destination network. This concept is known as the "longest prefix match" rule or "most specific route" rule.

I've seen this question somewhere else and the answer they gave for OSPF here wasn't the same, just think they trying to trick people but I hope what I shared can help anyone here new looking for explanation to this question like me.

A router evaluates routes in the following order.
1. Prefix Length - The longest-matching route is preferred first. Prefix length trumps all other route attributes.
2. Administrative Distance - In the event there are multiple routes to a destination with the same prefix length, the route learned by the protocol with the lowest administrative distance is preferred.
3. Metric - In the event there are multiple routes learned by the same protocol with same prefix length, the route with the lowest metric is preferred. (If two or more of these routes have equal metrics, load balancing across them may occur.)

comments.content: The question is a bit vague because in fact when I looked at it at the beginning was not sure what this script is about. If this script was to inform us that these are the routes in the router's routing table, then definitely D is the correct one based on longest match with the host inclusive. However, I at first thought that he might be showing the routes learned by the router through different protocols. In this case, we select the route with lowest AD. But we need to remember that these are 3 different routes to three different subnets and not to a single subnet. Henceforth no competition exist on to which to include and all 3 will be included in the routing table, which leads us to first assumption and answer is again the RIP route or D. This overthinking is justified, first, other similar questions used exibit of a show ip command for a question like this. Which causes no confusion. Moreover, in other cases, if theses were learned routes and not actual routes in the routing table, the answer can be different than if we assume that these are routes in routing table, luckley both led to same answer here

discussion.content:
Answer is wrong, why? Take a look at the address 192.168.12.16
if we choose C as the answer which is a /28, the increment for that CIDR is 16, meaning from the 4th octet it will be 0 ~ 16 , where 0 and 16 are network address respectively (192.168.12.0 ans 192.168.12.16). Now with this information Answer C violates the following:
1. You can use a network address as an ip address
1.1 Since you can use the network address as an ip address, the usable host range from 192.168.12.0 is only .1 ~ 14, since .15 is its broadcast address and .16 is well the next network address. so The answer is D, though the EIGRP route has way more space to accommodate the .16 since it is a CIDR /24, (255 host spaces) the RIP option (C.) is correct since it is way higher / longer than that of the /24 (/27 vs /24) and the fact that a /27 CIDR has 32 increments meaning 30 usable host from .1 ~ 30, where .0 is the network address and .31 is its broadcast followed by .32 which is the next network.
D is correct - RIP V1 does not support VLSM, however, RIP V2 does
The Correct Answer is D. Because the OSPF route 192.168.12.0/28 range is 192.168.12.1 - 192.168.12.16 it not include the destination address.
The Correct Answer is D. Because the Rip route 192.168.12.0/28 range is 192.168.12.1 - 192.168.12.16

questions.question_text: What are two reasons for an engineer to configure a floating static route? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Floating static routes are static routes that have an administrative distance greater than the administrative distance of dynamic routes. Administrative distances can be configured on a static route so that the static route is less desirable than a dynamic route. In this manner, the static route is not used when the dynamic route is available. However, if the dynamic route is lost, the static route can take over, and traffic can be sent through this alternate route. If this alternate route is provided using a DDR interface, then that interface can be used as a backup mechanism.

Used when primary route is Not available.
A and C are the same thing with different wording. :)

Selected Answer: AC
A & C are correct
The answer is literally the same. Just said 2 different ways

Selected Answer: AC
A and C are literally the same
A & C are correct

Selected Answer: AC
YES A and C

choices.B: to route traffic differently based on the source IP of the packet
choices.C: to automatically route traffic on a secondary path when the primary path goes down
choices.A: to enable fallback static routing when the dynamic routing protocol fails
choices.E: to control the return path of traffic that is sent from the router
choices.D: to support load balancing via static routing

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer must add a subnet for a new office that will add 20 users to the network. Which IPv4 network and subnet mask combination does the engineer assign to minimize wasting addresses?

discussion.content:
D is correct!

Find the subnet mask
*To have 20 User in a subnet We have to use /27 prefix 
* So Host count for /27 prefix is (2^5-2)=30
* Subnet Mask for /27 prefix is (sum of Network bits (128+64+32)=224 , so 255.255.255.224

Find the network ID

*As per the /27 prefix each subnet has 30 host and 32 including network ID & Broadcast ID
* so first network ID is 10.10.255.0 and the second will be 10.10.255.32

comments.content: Thank you
Sorry .128
I think there is a gap between the second and the third subnets, so we use .32 for the required network id, if more than 30, we need to use .64 as there are more space

Convert IP address and subnet mask to binary:

IP address: 10.10.225.48 becomes 00001010.00001010.11111111.00110000
Subnet mask: 255.255.255.224 becomes 11111111.11111111.11111111.11100000
Compare the first 27 bits:

Align the two binary strings and check if the first 27 bits (from left to right) are identical:

00001010.00001010.11111111.00110000 (IP address)
11111111.11111111.11111111.11100000 (Subnet mask)

The first 27 bits (highlighted) match perfectly.

10.10.225.48 255.255.255.224 Is a Valid Network ID: It might seem unusual at first glance, but it's indeed a valid network ID for a /27 subnet. Here's why:
The first 27 bits of 10.10.225.48 (in binary) match exactly with the first 27 bits of 255.255.255.224, fulfilling the requirement for a valid network ID within a /27 subnet.
This means the first three octets (10.10.225) and the first three bits of the fourth octet (001) are fixed for all IP addresses within this subnet, while the remaining 5 bits in the fourth octet can vary for host addresses.

discussion.content:
A. 10.10.225.48 255.255.255.240

This is a /28 subnet. 4 bits in the host ID. You have (2^4 – 2) = 14 addresses. But you need 20 more IP addresses.
Wrong answer.

B. 10.10.225.32 255.255.255.240

This is a /28 subnet. 4 bits in the host ID. You have (2^4 – 2) = 14 addresses. But you need 20 more IP addresses.
Wrong answer.

C. 10.10.225.48 255.255.255.224

This looks like a /27 subnet. 5 bits in the host ID. You have (2^5 – 2) = 30 addresses. Could be the right answer, but there’s a mismatch between the subnet ID and the subnet mask.

If you perform the logical AND between the subnet ID and the subnet mask, you should obtain the subnet ID:

Subnet ID 00001010.00001010.11111111.00110000
Subnet mask 11111111.11111111.11111111.11100000

Result 00001010.00001010.11111111.00100000

Decimal 10.10.255.32

This is not the subnet ID. Wrong answer.

D. 10.10.225.32 255.255.255.224

This is a /27 subnet. 5 bits in the host ID. You have (2^5 – 2) = 30 addresses. No mismatches between subnet ID and subnet mask.
Correct answer.

Talking about last octet here. Need 5 host bits to fit the desired usable IPs. Therefore, CIDR=/27 (32-5) which is dotted-decimal 224. Since 5 host bits are needed, that leaves the first 3 bits for network, so can fit only the 32 value (as the 48 value takes up 4 bits).
